title: How to Make Your Own Deep Conditioner

methods.name: Making a Deep Conditioner for All Hair Types

steps.headline: Put 8 tablespoons of coconut oil into a mixing bowl and stir it with a whisk until it becomes soft.
steps.description: You do not need to melt the coconut oil, but it should be at room temperature. The heat created by all that whisking will soften the oil up some more on its own. You are making enough deep conditioner to last you a few uses. If you plan on using this just one time, use only 2 tablespoons of coconut oil.

steps.headline: Add 4 tablespoons of jojoba oil.
steps.description: If you can't find any jojoba oil, you can also use argan oil, grapeseed oil, or olive oil. If you plan on using this deep conditioner just once, use 1 tablespoon of jojoba oil.

steps.headline: Add 15 to 20 drops of your favorite essential oil for fragrance.
steps.description: While this is not completely necessary, it will give your deep conditioner a nice smell. You can use any type of essential oil you want, such as clary sage, geranium, lavender, peppermint, rosemary, or peppermint. Some people find tea tree oil to be especially moisturizing when it comes to hair. If you are making a one-time-use mask, you will only need 3 to 4 drops of essential oil. Consider testing the essential oil on your inner arm first to see if you have an allergic reaction.

steps.headline: Apply the oil to your hair, starting from the roots.
steps.description: You do not need to apply all of the deep conditioner' you made enough to last several treatments. At most, you will only need 2 to 3 tablespoons in order to coat your hair. If you have very long hair, you may find it helpful to divide your hair into smaller sections first. If your hair is very oily, do not put any oil on your scalp. If you tend to get dandruff, however, massaging the oil into your scalp may help relieve some of it.

steps.headline: Tuck your hair under a plastic shower cap.
steps.description: This will help trap the heat and moisture, and make the mask more effective. If you do not have a plastic shower cap, a plastic bag will also work.

steps.headline: Wrap a hot towel around your head, and secure it with a hair clip, if needed.
steps.description: The heat from the towel will cause the hair follicles to open up. This will make it easier for your hair to absorb the oil. You can also simply heat your hair with a blow dryer for a few minutes, just don't take the shower cap off! A hooded dryer is a great option to heat your hair too, if you have one available to you.

steps.headline: Wait 3 to 5 minutes.
steps.description: Do not take the shower cap off during this time. If you wrapped a hot towel around your head earlier, leave it on as well. If you wish to get even more benefits out of this deep conditioner, leave it on for 15 to 30 minutes.

steps.headline: Wash the deep conditioner out with shampoo.
steps.description: You may have to shampoo your hair twice in order to get all of the coconut oil out. When you are done, simply style your hair as you usually do. Thanks to the deep conditioning you did earlier, you do not need to use any conditioner afterwards. If you have trouble removing the coconut oil from your hair with your regular shampoo, try washing once with a clarifying shampoo.

steps.headline: Store the rest of the deep conditioner in a glass jar.
steps.description: You can use this deep conditioner once every three weeks. If the oils separate, simply stir them up again with a spoon.

methods.name: Making a Deep Conditioner for Dry Hair

steps.headline: In a blender, combine one peeled banana and 2 to 3 tablespoons of extra-virgin olive oil.
steps.description: Keep blending until the mixture is smooth. Bananas are rich in potassium and vitamin A, both of which will help hydrate and strengthen your hair. The olive oil will help the deep conditioner soak into your hair. It will also help hydrate your hair and add shine as well.

steps.headline: Add ¼ cup (65 grams) of plain Greek yogurt and 1 tablespoon of honey.
steps.description: Yogurt is great for the hair because it is naturally hydrating. It is also full of proteins, which can help strengthen your hair. Honey, on the other hand, is a natural humectant, so it will help hydrate your hair and seal the moisture in.

steps.headline: Blend the mixture again until it is smooth, then pour it into a bowl through a strainer.
steps.description: The strainer will remove any lumps or clumps and give you a smoother conditioner to work with. Discard any lumps caught in the strainer.

steps.headline: Apply the conditioner to wet hair.
steps.description: Get into the shower, and dampen your hair. Spread the conditioner evenly through your hair. If you have very long or thick hair, you might find it helpful to separate your hair into smaller sections first. If you have any leftover conditioner, throw it out; it will not hold well, even in the fridge.

steps.headline: Tuck your hair under a plastic shower cap and wait 30 minutes.
steps.description: Leave the shower cap on during this time. If you'd like, you can wrap a warm towel around your head; this will help further trap the heat and make the mask more effective.

steps.headline: Rinse the conditioner out with warm water and shampoo.
steps.description: If you need to, apply some conditioner to the ends of your hair. After that, style your hair as you usually do.

methods.name: Making a Deep Conditioner for Damaged or Brittle Hair

steps.headline: Peel, pit, and mash one avocado.
steps.description: You can do this with a fork in a small bowl or in a blender. Avocados have lots of vitamins and essential fatty acids, which will help strengthen and restore your hair.

steps.headline: Put the avocado, 2 tablespoons of honey, and 1 tablespoon of extra-virgin olive oil into a blender.
steps.description: Honey is a humectant, so it will help draw and seal moisture into your hair; hydration is a big part of caring for damaged or brittle hair. The olive oil will help further penetrate and moisturize your hair.

steps.headline: Blend the ingredients together until they are smooth.
steps.description: If the ingredients are not mixing together evenly, pause the blender, and scrape any lumps or clumps down towards the bottom of the blender.

steps.headline: Apply the deep conditioner to wet hair.
steps.description: Dampen your hair first, then spread the deep conditioner throughout it. If you have long or thick hair, you might want to divide your hair into smaller sections first. If you have any leftover conditioner, throw it out; it won't last long.

steps.headline: Tuck your hair under a plastic shower cap, and wait one hour.
steps.description: To get even more out of this mask, wrap a warm towel around your head. The plastic shower cap will help trap heat and moisture, and make this mask more effective.

steps.headline: Rinse the mask off using warm water and shampoo.
steps.description: If you need to, apply some regular conditioner afterwards. Once your hair is clean, style is as your normally would.

methods.name: Making a Deep Conditioner for Weak or Brittle Hair

steps.headline: Whip an egg in a cup and set it aside.
steps.description: You can do this using a fork or mini whisk. Keep whisking until the yolk is all broken up, and mixed evenly with the white. Eggs are full of protein, which will help strengthen your hair. EXPERT TIP								Laura Martin			Licensed Cosmetologist				Did You Know? Eggs are highly beneficial for hair. They contain biotin and other proteins that promote growth and lots of good fats and vitamins that keep your hair healthy, strong, and glossy.

steps.headline: In a medium-sized mixing bowl, whip 1 cup (250 grams) of plain, Greek yogurt.
steps.description: Yogurt is packed with protein and lactic acid, both of which will help hydrate and strengthen your hair.

steps.headline: Add the whipped egg, 1 tablespoon of castor oil, and 1 tablespoon of coconut oil.
steps.description: The castor oil will help strengthen your hair, while the coconut oil will help nourish and moisturize it.

steps.headline: Whisk the ingredients together until they are evenly combined.
steps.description: Make sure that there are no streaks or swirls of unmixed egg yolk or oil.

steps.headline: Apply the mixture to wet hair.
steps.description: Dampen your hair first, then apply the mixture to it. If you have very long or thick hair, divide your hair into smaller sections first. If you have any mixture left over, discard it. Because this conditioner contains raw egg, be very careful not to get any on your face.

steps.headline: Tuck your hair until a plastic shower cap and wait one hour.
steps.description: Many people recommend heating your hair with a dryer, hot towel, or hood dryer to make deep conditioners more effective. This deep condition is an exception, so do not apply any heat to it, or you will risk cooking the eggs.

steps.headline: Rinse the deep conditioner out using cool water and shampoo.
steps.description: Do not use hot water or you will end up cooking the egg in the mask. Use the coolest water you can stand. If you need to, follow up with some regular conditioner.
